Thanks. I noticed from your Annual Report you have a currency exposure of around €7 billion – over here – around €7 billion to the Chinese renminbi. Is that a number you can keep stable over time as you grow your local production or should we expect that number to increase? And then maybe can you talk about what actions you can actually take to hedge against volatility on that currency? Thank you.
Mr. Eichiner?

Well, I think this exposure will grow over time as long as the economy is growing in China and as long as the markets are growing in China. Of course, we are hedging with the investments for the new plants and the ramp up of the local business, but as I said, as long as we are in a growing environment, as long as we see double-digit growth numbers there, the exposure is expected to grow. That's why we have to be prepared. But nobody knows how long this will take place. We have to take into account that this could end at a certain point in time. But for this year and maybe the next year, we still think that the business will see a chance to be grown in this country.
Next question, Laura and then Francois.

Yeah, thank you. I'm Laura Lembke from Morgan Stanley. I just have one question, you talked about returning money to shareholders. So, I was just wondering if you could give us a bit of an update on your dividend policy going forward, and also, if maybe a special dividend for 2012, I mean, financial year, would be compatible with your internal liquidity requirements? Thank you.

Well, I mean, we promised to you that we will bring the dividend payment into a range of 30% to 40%. We've taken the first huge step for 2011. Now we are at the lower end at 30.7%. So, we reached the range and we kept the promise. And I think we will look for the same approach for 2012 as well. If everything goes right, I think the range of 30% to 40% is something where we want to hold on, but I just ask you for your understanding before we talk of huge dividends. We first want to see how this year works out. We have now a few on two months of 2012 and I mean, this will be a discussion maybe we should have again at the end of the year when we are much more clearer what we really can earn in 2012.
Fine, next question, François Maury and then Philippe Barrier [SG Securities].

Thanks. François Maury, Oddo Securities. I have a question regarding the battery technology, the battery will represent a huge share of the – in the value chain of cars in the future. It seems that you are investing a lot in the battery field in the design, the chemistry. Does that mean that you intend to be fully integrated in the battery in the future? I mean in terms of production in terms of development? And could you remind us what are for you the main opportunities and the main risks to be integrated in this field?

I mean the battery technology, you have to differentiate in principle between two parts, one part are the cells and we see the cells at the moment, as a part we buy from another company. At the moment from SB LiMotive, as you know, the joint venture between Bosch and Samsung. So, that is one thing. What we like to do in the future and that was one of the reasons for the cooperation between the BMW Group and Toyota, to understand more about lithium-ion technology; to understand more what technologies can follow beyond lithium-ion; to be able to achieve for the car as a whole a better range in future, let me say, in the year 2020 or 2025. So, that is one part of it. At the moment, cells we buy from another company.

So, if you see the battery, we do the battery by ourself or let me say, in the joint venture, between BMW and PSA. And we will develop the battery, we will buy the cells, we will develop the battery, and what we will do as well, we will produce the battery. So – and as you said, I mean, the battery will be a very important part in future battery electric vehicles or as well plug-in hybrid cars. And we have to understanding – we have to understand how a battery can develop further. So, it has to be in our hand from a research and development point of view and from a production point of view. And as I said, cell technology at the moment, our knowhow is very little but we would like to be better, let me say, in five years, and that was one of the reasons for the cooperation between Toyota and BMW.
So, ladies and gentlemen, it's five minutes to twelve. I think, Philippe, you have the chance for the last question.

Okay. Please, follow-up question, first one regarding ING Lease, what do you expect in term of full-year contribution in 2012? Some deconsolidation of ING Lease? Second point is regarding the underlying topics behind the guidance of higher pre-tax profit. What do you expect in term of impact of derivatives as in 2011, there was a strong write-down regarding your derivative and financial currencies, what is the topic on that for 2012?

And the last question is regarding also the underlying profit of the contribution of the Chinese JV in 2012. Due to the expansion or introduction of new plant in 2012, do you think that the impact will be negative regarding the contribution of full year of the Chinese JV in 2012?
So, Mr. Eichiner?

Yeah. Let's start. Well, ING Car Lease profit contribution. ING Car Lease was always profitable even in the crisis. And it will contribute to Alphabet's profit with the beginning of 2012, that's absolutely clear. So, our expectation is that the profit of Alphabet will be in a low three-digit million number for 2012 and as I said, they will contribute. And both companies merged together are combining different strength and our market performance so far is promising. They could even grow the business in the fourth quarter by 9% and what we see for the beginning of this year makes us quite confident that the strategic target of this initiative will be achieved.

Of course, coming – in addition to the operational profit, we still have to carry some burden for the integration IT systems, processes and all those kind of stuff. This is something we have to take into consideration when you look at the overall profit. Now your question about the FX impact, especially stand-alone derivatives in the financial result. Well, that is always hard to predict because if you look where the dollar was on the last day of December, it was at $1.30/€, now it changed already. And you have to see just to make you understand why this is something we have to carry as a certain burden. It's part of our hedging and risk management strategy.

So, just to give you an example, we look at the buying power equilibrium when it comes down to the FX management, and in a situation where the currency is under weighted, I think undervalued, we go for options because at least there's some upside open. In a situation where it's overvalued, we go for forwards.

So, basically, that means you always have an amount of options as a kind of a worst-case protection in your – on your balance sheet. And this leads to a certain fluctuation in the financial result and we've seen this on the currency side with the strong dollar in 2012, which is good news on the other side because it means we had a positive influence on our revenues.

And your last question, China contribution. Well, I already – we discussed this already. I mean, we think also in 2012, the profit contribution of China will be in the range of 20% to 30% because our strategy is not to be dependent on China as much as maybe others are. We will not see a quite well-managed distribution of sales and profit around the globe in order to be more flexible at a point in time, where a crisis or a downturn in a specific region could come in. And that's the reason why we think 20% to 30% is still a very solid guidance for 2012.
My question just related to the contribution in the financial result of the Chinese JV mean that the impact in the financial result, the contribution of equity from the company?

From the joint venture, the equity. Okay, I mean our expectation is that this contribution will grow because we see a growing business within the joint venture. And at the end of the day, this will really have a positive influence on our financial result in the Automotive sector definitely.
So, ladies and gentlemen, we are on time. It is 12:00. Thank you very much. I now invite you all to join us for lunch. Mr. Reithofer and Mr. Eichiner will be present. Thank you very much.
